action.action-desc: Mr. Langevin (for himself, Mr. Russell, Mr. King of New York, and Mr. Capuano) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, and in addition to the Committee on House Administration, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To amend title 5, United States Code, to allow injured Federal law enforcement officers to continue to serve their agencies, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Continuation on Active Service Act.

section.header: Continued service of injured federal law enforcement officers

subsection.text: Chapter 33 of title 5, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:

section.header: Law enforcement officers; continued service after injury

subsection.text: An agency may waive any medical standards or physical requirements applicable to a position occupied by a law enforcement officer if the officer suffers a qualifying injury.
In carrying out subsection (a), the employing agency—

paragraph.text: may utilize a medical review board as established under the authority granted by this title;
may assign the officer duties that take the qualifying injury into account;
may not reduce the general schedule pay scale of the injured law enforcement officer who returns to work full-time after the incidence of injury even if the duties are adjusted; and
shall take into account the health and safety of the officer and others.

subsection.text: Not later than 60 days after the date of enactment of this section, the Office of Personnel Management shall promulgate regulations to carry out this section. Such regulations shall provide consistent application of this section, to the greatest extent practicable, in each employing agency.

A law enforcement officer who receives a waiver under this section shall be subject to the retirement benefits provisions under chapter 83 or 84 that would otherwise apply to the officer had the officer not suffered a qualifying injury.

paragraph.text: the term law enforcement officer has the meaning given such term in sections 8331(20) and 8401(17), and includes any member of the Capitol Police, the Supreme Court Police, or the United States Secret Service Uniformed Division; and
the term qualifying injury means an injury—

subparagraph.text: that results in the officer being unable to meet the medical standards or physical requirements otherwise required to occupy the applicable law enforcement position; and
is not due to misconduct, willful negligence, or incurred during an unauthorized absence.

subsection.text: The table of sections of such chapter is amended by adding after the item relating to section 3330e the following new item:

toc.toc-entry: 3330f. Law enforcement officers; continued service after injury.

paragraph.text: The authority provided by section 3330f of title 5, United States Code, as added by subsection (a), may be applied to any law enforcement officer who, before the date of enactment of this Act, suffered a qualifying injury (as that term is defined in such section).
An agency head shall submit a report to Congress with respect to each instance that the authority provided in paragraph (1) is exercised.
